Trimetallic synergistic optimization of 0D NiCoFe-P QDs anchoring on 2D porous carbon for efficient electrocatalysis and high-energy supercapacitor Ruiqi Liu a Xue-Rong Shi a ⁎ Yi Wen a Xiaoxuan Shao a Chen Su b Jing Hu c Shusheng Xu a ⁎ a School of Materials Engineering, Shanghai University of Engineering Science, Shanghai 201620, China School of Materials Engineering Shanghai University of Engineering Science Shanghai 201620 China School of Materials Engineering, Shanghai University of Engineering Science, Shanghai 201620, China b School of Advanced Materials and Nanotechnology, Xidian University, Xi’an 710071, Shaanxi, China School of Advanced Materials and Nanotechnology Xidian University Xi’an 710071 Shanxi China School of Advanced Materials and Nanotechnology, Xidian University, Xi’an 710071, Shanxi, China c School of Materials Science and Engineering, Suzhou University of Science and Technology, Suzhou 215009, Jiangsu, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Suzhou University of Science and Technology Suzhou 215009 Jiangsu China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Suzhou University of Science and Technology, Suzhou 215009, Jiangsu, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A gradient temperature construction of 0D/2D heterostructure with NiCoFe-P quantum dots anchoring on porous carbon for highly efficient overall water splitting and supercapacitor. Developing multi-functional and low-cost noble-metal-free catalysts such as transition metal phosphides (TMPs) to replace noble-metal is of practical significance for energy conversion and storage. However, the low-durability and the agglomeration phenomenon during the electrochemical process limit their practical applications. Herein, using metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) as the precursor and a combined strategy of gradient temperature calcination and thermal phosphorization, a 0D/2D heterostructure of NiCoFe-P quantum dots (QDs) anchored on porous carbon was successfully developed as highly efficient electrode materials for overall water splitting and supercapacitors. Owing to this distinctive 0D/2D heterostructure and the synergistic effect of multi-metallic TMPs, the NiCoFe-P/C exhibits excellent electrocatalytic activity and durability of HER (87 mV at 10 mA cm−2) and OER (257 mV at 100 mA cm−2) in the KOH electrolyte. When NiCoFe-P/C is used as the two electrodes of electrolyzed water, only 1.55 V can drive the current density to 10 mA cm−2. At the same time, our NiCoFe-P/C possessed extraordinary property for charge storage. In particular, an ultra-high energy density of 100.8 Wh kg−1 was achieved at a power density of 900.0 W kg−1 for our assembled hybrid supercapacitor device NiCoFe-P/C (2:1)//activated carbon (AC). This work may open a potential way for the design of 0D/2D hybrid multi-functional nanomaterials based on TMPs QDs. Keywords Metal-organic frameworks Transition metal phosphide quantum dots 0D/2D heterostructure Overall water splitting Supercapacitor First-principle calculations 1 Introduction Due to the high calorific value of hydrogen and excellent energy storage performance, electrochemical overall water splitting and supercapacitor play a crucial role in the coming energy revolution, promoting the transition to a sustainable and carbon neutral society [1–6]. Finding clean, cheap, and sustainable electrode materials is a critical strategy to achieve highly efficient energy conversion and storage. Pt and RuO2/IrO2 are ideal materials for electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) and oxygen evolution reactions (OER), which can effectively reduce the overpotential of the electrochemical reaction process [7]. Nevertheless, the scarcity and the high-cost limit their extensive application. Similar problems also appear for energy storage electrode materials [8,9]. In this regard, more and more researchers have made efforts to explore a series of non-noble transition metal-based compounds including metal oxides [10], hydroxides [11], sulfides [12], selenides [13], nitrides [14], and phosphides [15] for highly efficient overall water splitting and supercapacitor. Among potential candidates mentioned above, transition metal phosphides (TMPs) such as Ni2P, CoP, and FeP have got increasing interests due to their high conductivity, abundant earth reserves, and adjustable electronic structures [16]. However, the poor exposure ratio of active sites and unsatisfactory stability limits the application of TMPs as electrode for electrocatalytic water splitting and supercapacitors. To overcome these problems, many improvement methods have been proposed including interfacial engineering, elemental doping, structural engineering, phase modification, and nanocarbon incorporation [17]. Liu et al. have successfully synthesized Ni2P/CNT nanohybrid with excellent electrocatalytic activity due to the unexpected synergistic effect between Ni2P nanocrystals and nitrogen-doped rGO [18]. They found that the high conductivity of Ni and P is necessary to enhance the catalytic activity of HER. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are excellent precursors for preparing metal phosphides due to their high porosity and structural tunability, and the multi-metal phosphides obtained by this method can inherit the rich porous structure with abundant active sites for electrochemical reactions [19]. Recently, Chen et al. found that the existence of Ni2P/CoP interfaces in their synthesized Ni2P-CoP bimetallic phosphides by using MOFs as precursors is necessary for delivering the synergistic effect and enhancing electrocatalytic activity [20]. These discoveries are of great significance to the rational design and development of multi-component electrocatalysts for energy conversion and energy storage devices with high performances. However, the precise regulation of such heterogeneous interfaces is still challenging. Heterostructures based on 0D and 2D are particularly interesting in interface engineering. In the 0D/2D heterostructure, a very intimate interface is constructed through direct physical contact between the two phases. The physicochemical properties at the interface are quite different from the bulk phase. The strong interface interaction triggers the redistribution of electrons at the heterogeneous interface and consequently affects the reaction kinetics, conductivity, and adsorption energy of the intermediates. For instance, Kim et al. used a robust solution-phase and facile ex-situ sonication to form a 0D@2D Ni2P@NSG heterostructure [21]. Consequently, Ni2P@NSG electrocatalysts present high catalytic activity toward HER and OER in an alkaline electrolyte. Zhao et al. reported a Ni2P@NPC heterostructure with a strong coupling effect. The mutual stabilization of monodispersed TMPs nanocrystals and carbon nanosheets (NSs) makes the electrode material exhibit excellent electrochemical energy storage characteristics [22]. Nevertheless, there are few studies about 0D quantum dots (QDs), especially polymetallic phosphide QDs, interacting with 2D NSs to enhance electrocatalysis and energy storage properties have been reported. Based on the above analysis and our previous work [23], we herein propose a simple and unique design scheme to uniformly anchor TMPs QDs (<10 nm) on porous carbon NSs forming a special 0D/2D heterostructure. Using MOFs as precursors, low-dimensional and uniformly distributed QDs supported on 2D NSs were obtained through a gradient temperature calcination process. Subsequently, the obtained NiCoFe-P/C after thermal phosphating with a 0D/2D heterostructure shows super electrochemical performances in the electrocatalytic water splitting (including HER and OER) and supercapacitor. The obtained NiCoFe-P/C electrode presents impressive catalytic performances with an overpotential of 87 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for HER, 257 mV at 100 mA cm−2 for OER, and 34 h of stable running. The NiCoFe-P/C//NiCoFe-P/C electrolyzer only requires 1.55 V to reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2. In addition, the NiCoFe-P/C (2:1) can deliver an areal capacitance as high as 6.3 F cm−2 at 2 mA cm−2. Our work provides an inspiring synthesis strategy for the future application of multi-metallic phosphides with 0D/2D heterostructures in HER, OER, and supercapacitors. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of NiCoFe-ZIF precursor The NiCoFe-ZIF precursor is in-situ grown on Ni foam (NF) first. All chemicals with analytical-grade were directly used without further processing. NF (1 × 1 cm2) was pretreated in 1 M HCl for 30 min, and then washed with deionized water (DI) and ethanol for 15 min, respectively. In a typical solvothermal process, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.75 mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.75 mmol), and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.1 mmol) were dispersed in 17.5 mL methanol, and magnetically stirred to form a homogeneous solution. Similarly, C4H6N2 (4 mmol) was dissolved in 17.5 mL methanol, and after stirring, the obtained ligand solution was added to the methanol solution containing the mixed metal salts. After magnetic stirring for 20 min, the mixed solution and a piece of NF were placed in an autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 6 h. After cooling to room temperature, it was washed with DI and ethanol. Then, dried over night at 60 °C. The ratios of nickel salt and cobalt salt of 8:1, 2:1, 1:2, and 1:8 were considered to verify the effect of different ion ratios on the properties of composite materials. 2.2 Preparation of NiCoFe-P/C The NiCoFe-P/C 0D/2D heterostructure was fabricated by carbonization and phosphorization process of NiCoFe-ZIF precursors. A piece of NF supported NiCoFe-ZIF was annealed in N2 at 450 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 1.5 °C min−1, and after cooling down to room temperature, the NiCoFe-C was obtained. Then the sample was once again annealed and phosphated at 350 °C for 2 h under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 4 °C min−1, using NaH2PO2 as the phosphorus source. To ensure that the precursor is completely phosphatized, the NaH2PO2 is in excess (5.7 mmol). The mass loading of NiCoFe-P/C was about 4.3–4.8 mg cm−2. In order to explore the impact of the carbonization process on the material structure, NiCoFe-P/C-d was prepared for comparison, which was obtained by directly phosphating NiCoFe-ZIF without the carbonization process. 2.3 Materials characterization Ultra-55 Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) from Zeiss Company and Tecnai G2 F20 Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) from FEI Company were used to observe the morphological characteristics of the materials. Crystal structure and phase composition of the product are identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD, X'Pert Pro) measurements. The element content and chemical bond formed on the surface of the product are revealed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo K-Alpha+). In this research, Raman spectroscopy with 532 nm excitation laser was employed to confirm the composition of the products. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements All electrochemical tests were performed in 1 M KOH electrolyte (pH=14) using the electrochemical workstation (Chenhua CHI660E, Shanghai, China). First, HER and OER performances were tested using a three-electrode system. The synthesized material supported on NF was directly used as the working electrode. Ag/AgCl and carbon rod were used as a reference electrode and a counter electrode, respectively. Catalytic performance tests include linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) at frequencies of 0.1–100 kHz in a fixed potential window. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves were plotted at different scan rates (20, 40, 60, 80, and 100 mV s−1) to estimate the double-layer capacitance (C dl). Chronopotentiometry was conducted to test the stability of the samples under a fixed potential window. Moreover, CV curves, galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) curves, and EIS were used to verify the energy storage characteristics of as-fabricated nanomaterials. We used the traditional three-electrode system. Hg/HgO and platinum sheets were used as reference and counter electrodes, respectively. The NiCoFe-P/C (2:1) was used as anode and activated carbon (AC) was used as cathode to assemble the hybrid supercapacitor (HSC). Each EIS spectrum was fitted using the suggested equivalent circuit by the Zview program. The electrochemical calculation details were listed in the supporting information (SI). 2.5 Theoretical details The Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP) was used to perform the density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The parameters used are provided in SI. The ( 3 × 2 ) of the NiO(200) surface and (1 × 1) of Ni2P(111) with the close surface area are employed to perform the calculations. These two surfaces are clearly revealed in the XRD patterns with strong peak intensity and high resolution TEM (HRTEM) images. The following XPS analysis also shows that the content of Ni in the composites is higher than that of Fe or Co. Therefore, the Ni-series, namely, Ni-ZIF, NiO, and Ni2P, are chosen to perform the calculations. 3 Results and discussion Creating unique heterostructure structures based on interface engineering technology plays a key role in material modification. Herein, NiCoFe-P/C with a special 0D/2D (QDs/NSs) heterostructure was obtained by the combined strategy of solvothermal reaction and low-temperature calcination (Scheme 1 ). Initially, NiCoFe-ZIF NSs were obtained by the self-assembly between Ni2+, Co2+, Fe3+, and C4H6N2 to form coordination bonds. Then carbonization was carried out at 450 °C under N2 atmosphere, in which the carbon source comes from the ligand. After carbonization, the metal/metal oxide nanoparticles were uniformly supported on the carbon NSs. The carbon layer contains a small amount of N element, and the nitrogen source comes from the organic ligand as well. Different from the commonly used temperature in other reported works (≥700 °C) [24], a relatively low temperature, 450 °C, the most suitable temperature for our system, was taken to fulfill the carbonization. This low temperature treatment avoided the diffusion and agglomeration of nanoparticles caused by high temperature and effectively retained the porous structure of the precursor. At last, using NaH2PO4 as the phosphorus source, uniformly dispersed TMPs QDs were obtained on the surface of the porous carbon NSs under a slow heating rate, and some carbons were partially graphitized induced by the surrounding metal phosphide [25]. SEM and TEM were first performed to demonstrate the uniqueness of the sample in structure and morphology. Ultra-thin NiCoFe-ZIF (Fig. S1a and b) NSs were in-situ grown on the surface of NF uniformly, forming a crossed network and curled morphology, which is consistent with our previous research [23]. As illustrated in Fig. 1 (a–c), after the low temperature carbonization treatment, the 2D NSs morphology was still retained in NiCoFe-C (Fig. 1a). The main part of this sample was carbon that derived from the organic ligand. Furthermore, a more detailed description of the morphology and the interface structure of NiCoFe-C was presented in TEM (Fig. 1b). The dark nanoparticles anchored on the surface of porous carbon were metal/metal oxide QDs evolved from metal ions, which can be proved by the following XRD and HRTEM. The size of these QDs was mainly distributed around 8 nm. A lattice spacing of 0.203 nm is identified in the HRTEM, which matches well with the (111) plane of Ni, Co, and Fe crystals (Fig. 1c). To obtain the direct evidence for the existence of metal/metal oxide QDs, XRD of NiCoFe-C powder (without NF) was tested (Fig. S2). The subsequent XPS results (Fig. S7) reveal the existence of O elements in the prepared NiCoFe-ZIF precursor, which could be transformed to metal oxide during the carbonization process. After phosphating process, the 0D/2D heterostructure was fully reserved, in which metal atoms and metal oxides were converted into metal phosphide QDs and the carbon layer still acted as a protective layer and a substrate to maintain the dispersed state of the QDs (Fig. 1d and e). The size of the metal phosphides QDs is about 6–8 nm, which is a little smaller than that of metal/metal oxide QDs. The interplanar spacing of 0.221, 0.283, and 0.346 nm can be assigned to the (111), (011), and (001) planes of Ni2P, CoP, and Fe2P, respectively (Fig. 1f). The energy dispersive element mapping in Fig. 1(g) demonstrates the existence and uniform distribution of C, P, Co, Fe, and Ni. The porous properties of NiCoFe-P/C were further identified by the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm. As shown in Fig. S1(c and d), the specific surface area of NiCoFe-P/C is 85.03 m2 g−1. In addition, the microporous and mesoporous nanostructure of polymetallic phosphides with an average pore size distribution of 36.26 nm was further demonstrated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model. Given above, it is believed that NiCoFe-P QDs anchored on the porous carbon with multiple interfaces derived from MOFs have been successfully synthesized. In order to prove the importance of low-temperature carbonization process, NiCoFe-P/C-d, the product of direct phosphating the NiCoFe-ZIF precursor without the carbonization step, was also obtained for comparison. As revealed in Fig. S3(a–d), although the NiCoFe-P/C-d presents the similar 0D/2D heterostructure to the NiCoFe-P/C, a significant overlap between the carbon NSs and an obviously agglomeration between the TMPs QDs were observed. This further validates the advancement and ingenuity of the gradient temperature calcination strategy. The unique morphology will inevitably bring the surprising electrochemical performance to the composite material. To reveal the synergistic effect between different metal phosphides and obtain chemical state of the sample, XRD, Raman, and XPS were further performed. As depicted in Fig. 2 (a), the broad carbon diffraction peaks can be clearly observed in the XRD patterns of NiCoFe-C and NiCoFe-P/C. The fine diffraction peaks at 40.7°, 47.3°, 54.2°, 54.9°, and 74.6° were in perfect agreement with the (111), (210), (300), (211), and (400) surfaces of Ni2P [26]. Regardless of the strong diffraction peak of NF, the highest intensity diffraction peak, corresponding to the (111) crystal plane of Ni2P, is detected, which indicates that the optimal orientation is formed along the (111) direction in the NiCoFe-P/C heterostructure. To eliminate the influence of NF on the peak intensity, the XRD pattern of the final product at 10°–40° was tested (Fig. S4). The peak positions matched with the XRD patterns of CoP and Fe2P, which is consistent with the observation of TEM [25]. The XRD peaks of NiCoFe-P/C-d are similar to that of NiCoFe-P/C, but the peak intensity is weaker, in which the peak at 74.6° almost disappears (Fig. S5a). This may be due to the rapid phosphating process reducing the crystallinity of NiCoFe-P. Moreover, the evolution of carbon during the low-temperature carbonization is proved by the Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 2b). The characteristic peaks of NiCoFe-C were detected at about 1363 and 1583 cm−1, which result from the carbonization of dimethylimidazole. For NiCoFe-P/C, two characteristic peaks at about 1358 and 1585 cm−1 correspond to the D-band and G-band of graphene, which comes from the vibration of the defects and sp 2 hybridized carbon atoms, respectively. It is noting that the ratio of I G/I D in NiCoFe-P/C is higher than that in NiCoFe-C, indicating that more graphite carbons exist in NiCoFe-P/C than in NiCoFe-C. Namely, the presence of metal phosphides induced the formation of nearby graphite carbons during the phosphating process. The abundant graphite carbons are conductive to improve the conductivity of as-fabricated nanomaterials. It should be noted that the direct phosphorization of NiCoFe-ZIF to obtain NiCoFe-P/C-d may be associated with the carbonization processes simultaneously at 350 °C. However, the detected G peak of NiCoFe-P/C-d (Fig. S5b) is quite weak, indicating that the carbonization process is incomplete. Meanwhile, the I D/I G ratio of NiCoFe-P/C is higher than that of NiCoFe-P/C-d, suggesting NiCoFe-P/C may have abundant defects and expose more active sites for electrochemical reactions. XPS was further employed to analyze the electronic structure of the samples. The XPS survey spectrum of NiCoFe-P/C reveals the presence of the expected Ni, Co, Fe, C, N, and P (Fig. S6 and Table S1). As shown in Fig. 2(c), the Ni 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2 spectrum of NiCoFe-P/C can be deconvoluted to Ni3+ (859.9 and 877.1 eV) and Ni2+ (856.8 and 874.3 eV) in Ni-O, respectively [26]. The peaks at 853.5 and 870.8 eV come from the Ni-P along with the satellite peaks at 863.4 and 880.5 eV. The binding energy (BE) of Ni in Ni2P is slightly lower than that of Ni2+, indicating that the valence of Ni x + in Ni2P is 0 < x < 2. The Co 2p spectrum can be deconvoluted into two spin–orbit doublets (Fig. 2d) [27]. The first double peaks located at 777.4 and 792.0 eV were assigned to the stretching vibrations of the Co–P bond. The second double peaks at 782.0 (Co 2p 3/2) and 798.2 eV (Co 2p 1/2) were caused by the partial oxidation of the sample in air. Satellite peaks were detected at 786.3 and 803.3 eV. For Fe 2p spectrum (Fig. 2e), the peaks at 707.2 and 719.7 eV were characterized by Fe–P bonds [28]. The peaks at 710.8 and 723.4 eV can be attributed to surface Fe–O bonds. The other two peaks were attributed to satellite peaks. The high-resolution P 2p spectrum in Fig. 2(f) shows three peaks at 134.5, 133.7, and 129.8 eV, corresponding to P–O and M–P [29]. The results fully demonstrate the transformation of metals/metal oxides into metal phosphides. In addition, the XPS spectra of NiCoFe-ZIF and NiCoFe-C were shown in Figs. S7 and S8, which further provides evidence for the evolution of materials. Electrochemical tests were performed to evaluate the catalytic performance of NiCoFe-P/C, NiCoFe-ZIF, NiCoFe-C, NF, and reference electrode. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), the overpotential of NiCoFe-P/C is only 87 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2, which is much lower than those of NF (η 10 = 257 mV), NiCoFe-ZIF (η 10 = 234 mV), and NiCoFe-C (η 10 = 197 mV). NiCoFe-P/C exhibits the lowest overpotential, which is comparable to that of Pt/C. The superior HER performance of NiCoFe-P/C may be attributed to the co-contribution of the interfacial effect of the unique heterostructure and the synergistic effect of different metal phosphides. For NiCoFe-P/C, Ni species is considered to be the main active center. CoP and Fe2P QDs can adjust the electronic activity of the electrocatalysts [27]. The uniformly distributed ultra-thin carbon NSs favor the transmission of electrons, making NiCoFe-P/C exhibit high-conductivity (Fig. S9). As shown in Fig. 3(b and c), the calculated values of the Tafel slope and electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) further reveal the HER kinetic mechanism of the material. The Tafel slope of NiCoFe-P/C (80 mV dec–1) is smaller than those of NiCoFe-ZIF (167 mV dec–1) and NiCoFe-C (151 mV dec–1). Generally, HER is triggered by the Volmer (120 mV dec–1) step, and following this, it may proceed via a Heyrovsky (40 mV dec–1) step or a Tafel (30 mV dec–1) reaction. According to the obtained Tafel slope, the HER process on the NiCoFe-P/C electrode occurs through the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism, where the rate-determining step is the electrochemical desorption [30]. HER in the alkaline environment requires an additional water splitting reaction to provide H+ for the subsequent HER, which places higher requirements to the catalyst. The cleavage of the O–H bond in water molecules is promoted by the metal phosphides (Ni2P, CoP, and Fe2P) compared with the meta oxides precursor, which greatly improves the HER efficiency of NiCoFe-P/C under alkaline conditions, and this is confirmed by the following DFT calculations. The double layer capacitance (C dl) (Fig. 3c) was also calculated by using the CV curves under the narrow potential window (Fig. S10) and accordingly the ECSA was estimated to provide the ECSA-normalized LSV curves in Fig. S11. The C dl value of NiCoFe-P/C is about 21.3 m F cm−2, which is much higher than those of NiCoFe-ZIF (3.8 m F cm−2) and NiCoFe-C (7.4 m F cm−2). These results prove that NiCoFe-P/C possesses more active sites for the catalytic reaction than other fabricated samples. The disorder nature of interfaces between the poly-metal phosphides in the heterostructure leads to the increased reactivity and boots the generation and desorption of H2 at high current densities. Furthermore, NiCoFe-P/C also exhibited higher OER activity than NiCoFe-ZIF and NiCoFe-C, as shown in Fig. 3(d). At current densities of 50 and 100 mA cm−2, the overpotential of the NiCoFe-P/C is 254 and 257 mV, respectively. The overpotential is only increased by 3 mV, which means NiCoFe-P/C has ultra-fast reaction kinetics and high charge transfer efficiency. The Tafel slope of NiCoFe-P/C is only 20 mV dec–1, which is significantly lower than other catalysts including commercial electrode RuO2 (Fig. 3e). The OER reaction is considered to be a four-electron transfer process. The mechanism is very complicated, and its slow reaction kinetics process is an important factor hindering the efficiency of water electrolysis. Due to the unique 0D/2D heterostructure of NiCoFe-P/C, more reactive sites at the edge are exposed than other materials, which promotes the kinetics of the catalytic reaction. To explore the intrinsic activity, the turnover frequency (TOF) of the material was calculated to further illustrate the dynamic advantages of the material. The TOF of NiCoFe-P/C is as high as 1.36 s−1, which is much higher than other samples. These experimental results essentially show that the 0D/2D heterostructure with multiple components is very beneficial for exposing abundant active sites and thus improving the electrocatalytic activity. More importantly, the excellent durability of catalyst is also required for its practical application. The stability of the material was detected by the chronoamperometry measurement. Notably, the current density of the material basically unchanged during the 34 h test under a high voltage. No matter it is at a positive or negative voltage, the catalytic stability of NiCoFe-P/C is higher than those of NiCoFe-ZIF and NiCoFe-C (Fig. 3g and Fig. S12). In specific, we compared the LSV curves before and after the measurement, the overpotential value barely changes after the durability test and the structure also keeps well, as confirmed by XRD (Fig. S13). Fig. 3(h) presented a 3D histogram based on the LSV curves of NiCoFe-ZIF, NiCoFe-C, and NiCoFe-P/C to illustrate the overpotential of the samples under different current densities. Moreover, comparing the electrocatalytic properties of different phosphide materials in Tables S2 and S3, our NiCoFe-P/C also exhibits the competitive electrocatalytic performance. The catalytic performance of NiCoFe-P/C-d was also tested to illustrate the advantages of the gradient temperature carbonization strategy. For both HER and OER performances, NiCoFe-P/C-d exhibits inferior catalytic activities to NiCoFe-P/C with the higher overpotential and larger Tafel slope (Fig. S14). The difference of catalytic performances between NiCoFe-P/C-d and NiCoFe-P/C mainly comes from the changes in morphology and structure. The direct phosphorization process leads to the overlap of NSs and the agglomeration of nanoparticles, which greatly reduces the dispersibility of the nanoparticles, and the deterioration of performance is inevitable. The proportion of metal ions was also an important indicator for regulating electrochemical performance. Keeping the iron salt content unchanged, the content of nickel and cobalt salts in the precursor was adjusted. Similarly, a two-step calcination method was used to prepare metal phosphides with different nickel and cobalt ratios. The products were labeled as NiCoFe-P/C (8:1), NiCoFe-P/C (2:1), NiCoFe-P/C (1:2), and NiCoFe-P/C (1:8). According to the LSV, Tafel, EIS, and C dl results, when the ratio of Ni/Co is 8:1, 2:1, 1:2, and 1:8, the electrocatalytic performance of the hybrid materials is inferior to that of NiCoFe-P/C with Ni/Co ratio of 1:1 (Figs. S15 and S16). Thus, the suitable metal ratio is important for tuning the electronic structure of the nanocomposites and thus improving the electrocatalytic performance. Meanwhile, the change of morphology also affects its performance to a certain extent. All samples still maintain the original NSs structure, however, the NSs tend to agglomerate slightly, so some large nanoparticles are formed (Fig. S17). Fig. S18 shows the XRD patterns of the four samples. Compared with NiCoFe-P/C, no significant change in peak position was detected. Furthermore, a two-electrode electrolyzer was assembled by using the NiCoFe-P/C as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for overall water splitting. Only 1.55 V is required to obtain a current density of 10 mA cm−2, which is smaller than those of NiCoFe-C and NiCoFe-ZIF, suggesting NiCoFe-P/C has great application potential (Fig. 4 a). Additionally, under a fixed voltage, the chronoamperometry was performed to evaluate the stability of NiCoFe-P/C. The NiCoFe-P/C||NiCoFe-P/C electrolyzer can support the overall water splitting over 24 h with a slightly reduced activity, indicating the excellent durability of the 0D/2D NiCoFe-P/C heterostructure material (Fig. 4b). The recent achievements of TMPs used in water splitting are provided in Fig. 4(c) for comparison [31–42]. Obviously, our as-fabricated 0D/2D NiCoFe-P/C delivers super catalytic performances, outperforming most of reported relevant materials. Different from the scenario of the OER or HER catalytic performance, the NiCoFe-P/C (2:1) electrode exhibits the best energy storage characteristics among all the prepared composites. This may be due to that when the ratio of nickel and cobalt is 2:1, the two metal ions achieve the best electronic coordination effect and exhibit the best electrochemical performance. The similar phenomenon was also observed in our previous work for NiCo-based sulfides, where bimetallic sulfides exhibit the highest energy storage performance at the ratio of nickel to cobalt of 2:1 [23]. NiCoFe-ZIF (2:1), NiCoFe-C (2:1), and NiCoFe-P/C (2:1) electrode materials present similar CV curves with obvious redox peaks at a scan rate of 6 mV s−1 (Fig. 5 a). NiCoFe-P/C presented a higher redox peak than pure NF, which indicates that the electrochemical activity is mainly provided by the polymetallic phosphides rather than NF. For NiCoFe-P/C (2:1), as the scan rate increased, the redox peak positions shifted to the two ends respectively, while the curve shape maintained well, indicating that the material has good charge and discharge reversibility (Fig. S19a). When the scan rate is increased to 8 mV s−1, the redox peak becomes inconspicuous. This is because electrons cannot fully enter the interior of the material under the high current density. Fig. 5(b) and Fig. S19(b) list the GCD curves of NiCoFe-P/C (2:1). Clearly, the curves exhibit a relatively symmetric shape and an obvious discharge platform. At the current densities of 2 and 20 mA cm−2, the areal capacitances of the NiCoFe-P/C (2:1) electrode are 6.3 and 3.2 F cm−2, respectively, yielding a rate performance of 50.8% (Fig. S19c). The NiCoFe-P/C (2:1) electrode presented higher charge storage capacity than other TMPs (Table S4). During the charging and discharging process, the solution resistance (R s) and the charge transfer resistance (R ct) will hinder the diffusion and transfer of electrons. NiCoFe-P/C (2:1) owns a low R s (1.408 Ω) and R ct (0.106 Ω), which is also one of the reasons for its ultra-high areal capacitance (Fig. S19d). Benefiting from the unique 0D/2D heterostructure, NiCoFe-P/C possesses the largest charge storage capacity and the fastest electron diffusion and transfer channels among the considered materials. At a high current density of 40 mA cm−2, the cycle performance shows that after 5000 charge–discharge cycles, the capacitance loss is 16.5% (Fig. 5c). For comparison, Fig. S20 provides the CV and GCD curves of NiCoFe-P/C (8:1), NiCoFe-P/C (1:1), NiCoFe-P/C (1:2), and NiCoFe-P/C (1:8) to prove that the proper ratio of Ni and Co is essential for tuning the electrochemical performance. The energy storage mechanism of NiCoFe-P/C (2:1) was analyzed in Fig. 5(d–f). According to previous reports [43], the charge storage process includes the capacitance control (k 1 v, orange part) and diffusion control process (k 2 v 1/2, black part). The capacitance contribution rate and peak current are positively and exponentially correlated with the scan rate, respectively. The calculated b value of the cathodic and anodic peaks of NiCoFe-P/C is 0.5702 and 0.6195, respectively, indicating that the energy storage of NiCoFe-P/C presents both the battery and pseudocapacitance type characteristics. A further analysis (Fig. 5f) reveals that the energy storage is dominated by the diffusion process. The excellent performance of NiCoFe-P/C may come from the following aspects. (1) NiCoFe-P/C (2:1) is tightly combined with NF substrate, which helps electron transport in the electrochemical process. (2) Mixed metal phosphides have diverse ion valences, providing many possibilities for redox reactions. (3) The strong electronic coupling in the 0D/2D heterostructure brings the small resistance and enhanced stability to the material. Furthermore, the electrochemical performances of the HSC assembled by NiCoFe-P/C (2:1) and AC were shown in Fig. 6 (a–f). The mass loading of the anode (4.6 mg) and cathode (16.2 mg) of the HSC device is reasonably matched according to Eq. (8) in SI. Fig. 6(a) shows the CV curves of the anode and cathode at the scan rate of 2 mV s−1, and the voltage windows are 0–0.6 V and −1.0–0 V, respectively. To explore the optimal voltage window of the HSC device, the CV curve of the device under different voltage conditions was checked. When the voltage reaches 1.8 V, the CV curve is still not significantly deformed (Fig. S21a). Under this voltage, the actual energy storage of the device was further evaluated. The CV curves of the device at different scan rates are shown in Fig. 6(b). The faint redox peaks in the curve can be observed, indicating that the device has the characteristics of both electric double-layer capacitance and pseudocapacitance. The GCD curves and capacitance retention rate were also detected in Fig. 6(c) and Fig. S21(b). The GCD curves of the HSC device under different current densities of 1 to10 A g−1 also show a non-standard triangular shape, which is consistent with the CV curves. Electrochemical impedance is an important parameter for supercapacitors. According to the analysis of the impedance data on the equivalent circuit, the values of R s and R ct were 0.679 and 4.504 Ω, respectively (Fig. 6d). The small semicircle diameter in the high-frequency region and the large slope in the low-frequency region verified the good conductivity of the material and fast charge transfer at the interface, resulting the excellent electrochemical performances of HSC devices. The low resistance may originate from the special porous 0D/2D structure, which provides abundant active sites and reaction interfaces. Not surprisingly, the HSC device shows excellent stability (Fig. 6e). After 10,000 cycles of the GCD test, the specific capacitance of the material maintains 98.2% of the initial value. The Ragone diagram of the HSC device is shown in Fig. 6(f). The HSC device reaches an energy density of 100.8 Wh kg−1 at 900 W kg−1. When the maximum power density is 9000 W kg−1, the energy density still remained at 50.5 Wh kg−1. The performances of our assembled HSC surpass the recently reported studies [44–49]. Besides, the ultra-high energy density can support the light emitting diode (LED) to light up for about 1 min at 1.8 V. To comprehend the origin behind the electrochemical performances of various as-fabricated materials, the electronic properties and corresponding reaction mechanisms were explored by the DFT calculations. According to the above XRD, XPS, and HRTEM results, the Ni-series, namely, Ni-ZIF, NiO, and Ni2P are chosen to shed a light on the catalytic nature of these composites. As revealed in Fig. 7 (a), the band gap of the bulk materials is ordered of Ni-ZIF > NiO > Ni2P. The bulk Ni-ZIF and NiO show semiconductor properties with the band gaps of about 2.1 and 1.8 eV, respectively, while the Ni2P shows metallic characteristics with some states across the Fermi level. Consequently, Ni2P is expected to exhibit the best electronic conductivity, which is followed by NiO. This is consistent with the above EIS results and previous experimental and theoretical observations [50–52]. The projected density of states (PDOS) calculations reveals that more states appear near the Fermi level for Ni2P(111) compared to the other systems. According to our previous calculation [53], the closer d or p band center to the Fermi level means the stronger bonding strength to the adsorbates, which is confirmed by the cases of OH and H adsorption. As shown in Fig. 7(d–g), the H and OH adsorption strength decreases in the sequence of adsorbates-Ni2P(111) > adsorbates-NiO(200) > adsorbates-Ni-ZIF (The more negative the adsorption energy E ads value, the stronger adsorption it is). The strongest H adsorption on the hollow site formed by three surface Ni atoms on Ni2P(111) yields the closest |ΔG| value to 0 (Fig. 7g), suggesting its best HER performance, in line well with the experimental observation. Similarly, the OH adsorption, which is strongly related to the capacitive behavior of the as-fabricated materials by involving in the faradaic process, is thermodynamically preferred on Ni2P(111) over on the NiO(200) and Ni-ZIF. Notably, besides the d orbitals of surface Ni, the p orbitals of surface O in NiO(200) and surface P atoms in Ni2P(111) show up near/at the Fermi level as well, indicating that their contributions to the electronic conductivity and adsorbing the reaction species can be ignored. For instance, the most favorable H adsorption site on NiO is the top site of surface O. And OH prefers to locate at the top site of surface P on Ni2P(111). Moreover, the calculated electron localization function (ELF) shows that the surface electrons of NiO(200) are delocalized compared to those of Ni2P(111), where the electron cloud (in green) does not appear until the isosurface value equals 0.67 (Isosurface value = 1.0 means that the electron is totally localized). At this value, the electrons localized near the O atoms of NiO(200) and P atoms of Ni2P(111) arise, suggesting that these atoms show the trend to form covalent band with the adsorbates. As mentioned in the above discussion of the experimental results, HER in the alkaline environment requires an additional water splitting reaction to provide H+ for the subsequent HER. The calculation starts with H2O adsorption and its following dissociation to produce co-adsorbed H and OH. It is found that H2O adsorption on Ni2P(111) is slightly less stable than that on NiO(200) with the E ads of −0.27 vs. −0.46 eV for the most stable H2O adsorption configuration on the top site of surface Ni [50–52]. This is different from the scenarios of H and OH adsorption, which can be attributed to the extra formed H bond between the H2O molecule and surface O of NiO(200). Although H2O shows the slightly favorable adsorption on NiO(200), its following dissociation requires to cross a much higher reaction barrier than that on Ni2P(111) (1.97 vs. 1.35 eV, Fig. 7h and Fig. S23). Note that when the dissociation of H2O begins from its adsorption on the second most stable site on Ni2P(111), a top site of another surface Ni with E ads of −0.20 eV (Fig. 7h, only 0.07 eV higher than the most stable one). The dissociation barrier is reduced to be 0.78 eV. Apparently, the cleavage of the O–H bond in water molecules is promoted by Ni2P compared to the NiO, which greatly improves the HER efficiency of NiCoFe-P/C under alkaline conditions. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have proposed a simple and controllable gradient temperature calcination method to anchor 0D TMPs QDs on 2D porous carbon NSs. The formed NiCoFe-P/C exhibits excellent electrocatalytic activities and durability of HER and OER in the KOH electrolyte with η 10 of 87 mV for HER and η 100 of 257 mV for OER, respectively. Both of them can work steadily for 34 h at the high voltage. The assembled NiCoFe-P/C//NiCoFe-P/C electrolyzer exhibited superior overall water splitting characteristics (1.55 V at 10 mA cm−2). More importantly, an HSC device assembled with commercial AC and NiCoFe-P/C (2:1) reached an ultra-high energy density of 100.8 Wh kg−1 at the powder density of 900.0 W kg−1. This dual-function feature mainly comes from the designed unique 0D/2D heterostructure and the synergistic effect between the components in poly-metal phosphides. First, the rich porous structure inheriting from the MOFs precursor and the 0D shape of phosphides guarantee a large specific surface area to expose massive reactive sites. Secondly, a variety of metal phosphides derived from multi-metal MOFs, including Ni2P, CoP, and Fe2P, provide various types of active sites for the electrochemical reaction and the synergistic effect between the components promotes the kinetic process of catalysis and energy storage. In addition, the monodispersed nature of NiCoFe-P QDs avoids the overlapping and contact between the particles, thereby reducing the agglomeration in the process of chemical reactions and results in the excellent stability. We expect that the comprehensive utilization of the synergistic effects between the components and the unique 0D/2D heterostructure emphasized in this work may inaugurate a new way to explore cost-effective and multi-functional electrode materials. coredata.dc:description: Developing multi-functional and low-cost noble-metal-free catalysts such as transition metal phosphides (TMPs) to replace noble-metal is of practical significance for energy conversion and storage. However, the low-durability and the agglomeration phenomenon during the electrochemical process limit their practical applications. Herein, using metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) as the precursor and a combined strategy of gradient temperature calcination and thermal phosphorization, a 0D/2D heterostructure of NiCoFe-P quantum dots (QDs) anchored on porous carbon was successfully developed as highly efficient electrode materials for overall water splitting and supercapacitors. Owing to this distinctive 0D/2D heterostructure and the synergistic effect of multi-metallic TMPs, the NiCoFe-P/C exhibits excellent electrocatalytic activity and durability of HER (87 mV at 10 mA cm−2) and OER (257 mV at 100 mA cm−2) in the KOH electrolyte. When NiCoFe-P/C is used as the two electrodes of electrolyzed water, only 1.55 V can drive the current density to 10 mA cm−2. At the same time, our NiCoFe-P/C possessed extraordinary property for charge storage. In particular, an ultra-high energy density of 100.8 Wh kg−1 was achieved at a power density of 900.0 W kg−1 for our assembled hybrid supercapacitor device NiCoFe-P/C (2:1)//activated carbon (AC). This work may open a potential way for the design of 0D/2D hybrid multi-functional nanomaterials based on TMPs QDs.
